replies.bodyText: May I ask how assertDoesNotThrow test more than running (since it fails if it throws)
replies.author: Arthur-Milchior

replies.bodyText:
I think it's mostly an optimization vs Codacy saying "you should assert in a test"

/** Helper to sort out "JUnit tests should include assert() or fail()" quality check */
replies.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText:
You get an assertion error, rather than a method throwing an exception - which the tools detect differently
It's also more explicit that one specific line is under test.
